training_pairs.question: When was the policy about title fees waiving and refunding implemented?
training_pairs.answer: The policy was implemented on 7 September 2020
training_pairs.source_text:
7 September 2020 
  
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees 
Policy 2020 
 
LINZ OP O 01249 
 
Office of Registrar-General of Land

training_pairs.question: What government organization issued this policy document?
training_pairs.answer: The Office of Registrar-General of Land (LINZ) issued this policy document, with reference number OP O 01249
training_pairs.source_text:
7 September 2020 
  
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees 
Policy 2020 
 
LINZ OP O 01249 
 
Office of Registrar-General of Land

training_pairs.question: What appears to be the main purpose of this policy document?
training_pairs.answer: The main purpose appears to be establishing guidelines for waiving and refunding title fees, as indicated by the policy title

training_pairs.answer: The Registrar-General of Land has authority over this policy

training_pairs.question: What are the main sections covered in this policy document's contents?
training_pairs.answer: The policy document contains four main sections: About this policy, Purpose, Definitions and terms, Context, and Statutory Matters, all appearing on page 2 of 8

training_pairs.question: How is this policy document structured in terms of its numbering system?
training_pairs.answer: The document uses a hierarchical numbering system starting with section 1 (About this policy) and continuing with subsections 1.1 through 1.4 for Purpose, Definitions and terms, Context, and Statutory Matters

training_pairs.question: What can we infer about the purpose of this document based on its title and structure?
training_pairs.answer: This appears to be a formal policy document from 2020 that outlines the rules and procedures for waiving and refunding title fees, with a structured approach covering definitions, context, and legal requirements

training_pairs.question: What sections are listed between 1.4 and 2.1 in this document's structure?
training_pairs.answer: The sections listed are: 1.4 Statutory Matters, 1.5 Policy Objective, 1.6 Status of examples, 1.7 Application of this policy, 2. The Policies, and 2.1 Title fees may be waived or refunded

training_pairs.question: How is the document organized in terms of numbering structure?
training_pairs.answer: The document uses a hierarchical decimal numbering system, starting with major sections (1.x) and progressing to subsections (2.x), with each section having a descriptive title following the number

training_pairs.question: What appears to be the main policy topic discussed in section 2.1?
training_pairs.answer: Section 2.1 addresses the waiving or refunding of title fees, suggesting this is a policy document related to fee management

training_pairs.question: What are the main circumstances under which title fees can be waived or refunded according to the text?
training_pairs.answer: Title fees can be waived or refunded in several situations: when a service should have been free, when the purchased service wasn't required, when charging a fee isn't justified, when multiple fees are unreasonably charged, when correcting LINZ errors, and when an instrument is withdrawn before registration.

training_pairs.question: How does the text organize different scenarios for fee adjustments?
training_pairs.answer: The text organizes scenarios in seven numbered sections (2.1 through 2.7), each addressing a specific circumstance where fees might be waived or refunded, with corresponding page numbers ranging from 5 to 8.

training_pairs.question: Why might someone need to refer to section 2.6 specifically?
training_pairs.answer: Someone would refer to section 2.6 if they need information about fee adjustments related to correcting an error or omission made by LINZ (Land Information New Zealand).

training_pairs.question: What are the two main sections covered in points 2.7 and 2.8 of this text?
training_pairs.answer: The two main sections cover the withdrawal of instruments before registration or notation (2.7) and maintaining the integrity of title to estates and interests in land (2.8).
training_pairs.source_text:
2.7. An instrument is withdrawn before being registered or noted  ................................ ..................  8 
2.8. Maintaining the integrity of title to estates and interests in land  ................................ ..............  8

training_pairs.question: Why would it be important to have procedures for withdrawing instruments before registration?
training_pairs.answer: Having procedures for withdrawing instruments before registration helps maintain legal and administrative order in land registry systems, preventing incomplete or incorrect registrations from being processed.
training_pairs.source_text:
2.7. An instrument is withdrawn before being registered or noted  ................................ ..................  8 
2.8. Maintaining the integrity of title to estates and interests in land  ................................ ..............  8

training_pairs.question: How does maintaining the integrity of title to estates relate to land administration?
training_pairs.answer: Maintaining title integrity is fundamental to land administration as it ensures the reliability and accuracy of property ownership records and protects the legal interests of landholders.
training_pairs.source_text:
2.7. An instrument is withdrawn before being registered or noted  ................................ ..................  8 
2.8. Maintaining the integrity of title to estates and interests in land  ................................ ..............  8

training_pairs.question: What is the primary purpose of this policy document?
training_pairs.answer: This regulatory policy is designed to guide the Registrar on when title fees can be waived or refunded, either partially or in full.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 3 of 8 
1. About this policy  
1.1. Purpose 
This regulatory policy guides the Registrar as to circumstances when all or any part of a 
title fee may be waived or refunded.  
1.2. Definitions and terms 
In this policy, unless the context otherwise requires— 
Term Definition 
Amount means monetary worth  
Charged means a customer has been invoiced for a fee or has paid  
a fee 
Customer means a natural person or organisation who has purchased a 
service provided under the LTA or the LTR  
Dealing means dealing in estates and interests in land 
Estate or interest means every estate or interest in land, and includes a 
mortgage or charge on land 
Fee schedule Schedule 7 of the LTR 
Fraud has the meaning given to it in section 6 of the LTA 
Individual means a natural person 
Instrument has the meaning given to it in section 5 of the LTA 
LINZ Land Information New Zealand 
LTA Land Transfer Act 2017 
LTR Land Transfer Regulations 2018

training_pairs.question: How does this policy define a 'customer' and what services are they associated with?
training_pairs.answer: A customer is defined as either a natural person or organization who has purchased services provided under the Land Transfer Act (LTA) or Land Transfer Regulations (LTR).

1.2. Definitions and terms

LINZ Land Information New Zealand 
LTA Land Transfer Act 2017 
LTR Land Transfer Regulations 2018

training_pairs.question: What's the relationship between 'estate or interest' and 'dealing' according to the definitions?
training_pairs.answer: An estate or interest refers to any estate or interest in land, including mortgages or charges, while dealing specifically refers to transactions involving these estates and interests in land.

training_pairs.question: What is LINZ and how does it relate to the Land Transfer Act?
training_pairs.answer: LINZ stands for Land Information New Zealand, and it operates within the framework of the Land Transfer Act 2017 (LTA), which provides the legal basis for land registration and transfer in New Zealand.
training_pairs.source_text:
Individual means a natural person 
Instrument has the meaning given to it in section 5 of the LTA 
LINZ Land Information New Zealand 
LTA Land Transfer Act 2017 
LTR Land Transfer Regulations 2018 
Registrar means Registrar-General of Land 
Service means the performance or exercise of a function, duty or 
power under the LTA or the LTR 
Title fee means a fee payable under the LTA 
Titles resubmission fee means the fee that is charged when an instrument that has 
been requisitioned or rejected is re-submitted (section 37 of 
the LTA)

training_pairs.question: Can you explain what happens when a titles resubmission fee is charged?
training_pairs.answer: A titles resubmission fee is charged when an instrument that has been previously requisitioned or rejected needs to be re-submitted, as specified under section 37 of the Land Transfer Act.
training_pairs.source_text:
Individual means a natural person 
Instrument has the meaning given to it in section 5 of the LTA 
LINZ Land Information New Zealand 
LTA Land Transfer Act 2017 
LTR Land Transfer Regulations 2018 
Registrar means Registrar-General of Land 
Service means the performance or exercise of a function, duty or 
power under the LTA or the LTR 
Title fee means a fee payable under the LTA 
Titles resubmission fee means the fee that is charged when an instrument that has 
been requisitioned or rejected is re-submitted (section 37 of 
the LTA)

training_pairs.question: What's the difference between a Title fee and a Titles resubmission fee?
training_pairs.answer: A Title fee is any fee payable under the Land Transfer Act, while a Titles resubmission fee is specifically charged only when an instrument must be re-submitted after being requisitioned or rejected.

been requisitioned or rejected is re-submitted (section 37 of 
the LTA)

training_pairs.question: What is the main principle that underpins the fee waiver policies according to the text?
training_pairs.answer: The main principle is that customers should not have to pay fees where it is either unreasonable/unfair or necessary to maintain the integrity of title to estates and interests in land, and where the LTA permits the fee to be waived or refunded.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 4 of 8 
Term Definition 
Waiver means to dispense with the payment of a fee in accordance 
with section 229(3) of the LTA or regulation 23 of the LTR 
Working day has meaning given to it in section 5 of the LTA 
1.3. Context 
The principle1 that underpins the policies in this document are customers should not have 
to pay fees where— 
(a) it is—  
(i) unreasonable or unfair; or 
(ii) necessary to maintain the integrity of title to estates and interests in land; 
and 
(b) the LTA permits the fee to be waived or refunded. 
1.4. Statutory Matters 
1.4.1  Section 229(3) of the LTA  
Section 229(3) LTA Fees and charges states the Registrar may— 
(a) dispense with payment of all or any part of a fee payable under this Act; or 
(b) refund all or any part of a fee paid under this Act. 
1.4.2  Regulation 23 of the LTR 
Regulation 23(3) of the LTR Withdrawing instruments after lodgement states:

training_pairs.question: How does the text define a 'waiver' in the context of title fees?
training_pairs.answer: A waiver is defined as dispensing with the payment of a fee in accordance with section 229(3) of the LTA or regulation 23 of the LTR.

training_pairs.question: What authority does the Registrar have regarding fees according to Section 229(3) of the LTA?
training_pairs.answer: The Registrar has the authority to either dispense with payment of all or any part of a fee payable under the Act, or refund all or any part of a fee that has already been paid under the Act.

training_pairs.question: What is the primary policy objective described in the text?
training_pairs.answer: The primary policy objective is to provide a system of principles to guide decision making when considering waivers and refunds of title fees, based on judgements typically applied under normal business conditions.
training_pairs.source_text:
(b) refund all or any part of a fee paid under this Act. 
1.4.2  Regulation 23 of the LTR 
Regulation 23(3) of the LTR Withdrawing instruments after lodgement states:  
All or any part of a fee payable or paid under the Act in respect of the withdrawn 
instrument may be dispensed with or refunded (see section 229(3) of the Act). 
1.5. Policy Objective 
The substantive policy objective is to provide a system of principles to guide decision 
making when considering waivers and refunds of title fees, reflecting judgements that are 
ordinarily applied under business as usual conditions.  
 
 
 
1 LINZ Legal Services advice

training_pairs.question: How do Regulation 23 of the LTR and Section 229(3) of the Act relate to each other?
training_pairs.answer: Regulation 23 of the LTR refers to Section 229(3) of the Act regarding the authority to dispense with or refund all or part of fees paid for withdrawn instruments.

ordinarily applied under business as usual conditions.

training_pairs.question: Why might there be a need for guidelines on fee waivers and refunds?
training_pairs.answer: The text suggests that decision-making regarding fee waivers and refunds needs to be guided by consistent principles, ensuring that judgments are applied systematically under normal business conditions rather than being made arbitrarily.

training_pairs.question: What are the four specific circumstances under which title fees may be waived or refunded according to the policy?
training_pairs.answer: According to section 2.1, title fees may be waived or refunded when: 1) a service is supposed to be free of charge, 2) a customer purchases an unnecessary service based on LINZ guidance, 3) the amount of work doesn't justify charging a fee, and 4) charging multiple fees in a particular case would be unreasonable.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 5 of 8 
1.6. Status of examples 
The examples used in this policy only illustrate the provisions they relate to. They do not 
limit the provisions.  
1.7. Application of this policy  
This policy applies to:  
(a) all fees payable under the LTA, and 
(b) persons, classes of persons and holders of offices who have been delegated 
the powers and duties specified in section 229(3) of the LTA and in  
regulation 23 of the LTR. 
2. The Policies  
2.1 Title fees may be waived or refunded  
The policy is the Registrar will consider waiving or refunding all or any parts of title fees 
where— 
(a) a service is supposed to be provided free of charge: 
(b) a customer acting on the guidance of LINZ has purchased a service they do 
not require: 
(c) the amount of work in a particular case does not justify charging a fee: 
(d) it is unreasonable to charge multiple fees in a particular case:

training_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding fees that were incorrectly charged for services that should have been free?
training_pairs.answer: If a customer has been charged a fee for a service that should have been free, and less than 21 working days have elapsed since the charge, the policy states that the fee will be waived or refunded.
training_pairs.source_text:
not require: 
(c) the amount of work in a particular case does not justify charging a fee:

(e) the Registrar is correcting an error or omission by LINZ: 
(f) a customer has withdrawn an instrument before it is registered or noted: 
(g) it is necessary to maintain the integrity of title to estates and interests in land.  
2.2. A service supposed to be provided free of 
charge 
(1) If a customer is to be charged a fee for a service which is supposed to be provided 
free of charge, the policy is that the fee will be waived. 
(2) If a customer has been charged a fee for a service which was supposed to be 
provided free of charge and less than 21 working days have elapsed since the fee was 
charged, the policy is that fee will be waived or refunded.  
(3) To avoid doubt, the circumstances in which a service is supposed to be provided free 
of charge include (but is not limited to) where—

training_pairs.question: Under what circumstances would LINZ waive fees according to the text?
training_pairs.answer: LINZ would waive fees when: the amount of work doesn't justify charging a fee, multiple fees would be unreasonable, LINZ is correcting their own error, a customer withdraws an instrument before registration, or when necessary to maintain land title integrity.

training_pairs.question: What are the conditions required for waiving a titles resubmission fee?
training_pairs.answer: A titles resubmission fee can be waived when two conditions are met: 1) the fee is specifically a titles resubmission fee, and 2) the instrument being re-submitted has a nil registration or lodgement fee in the fee schedule. This is exemplified by the case of a re-submitted Gazette notice.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 6 of 8 
(a) the fee is the titles resubmission fee; and  
(b) the instrument being re-submitted has a nil registration or lodgement fee 
attached to it in the fee schedule. 
Example: 
A Gazette notice is re-submitted. The Registrar elects to waive the titles 
resubmission fee, because the fee for registering a Gazette notice is nil. 
2.3. The purchased service is not required 
If a customer acting on the guidance of LINZ has purchased a service they do not require 
and less than 21 working days have elapsed since the title fee was charged, then in 
determining whether to waive or refund all or any part of the fee, the Registrar will 
ordinarily consider (but is not limited to) the following matters: 
(a) the extent to which any guidance provided to customer by LINZ contributed 
to the purchase: 
(b) whether it was reasonable for the customer to rely on the guidance provided 
by LINZ:

training_pairs.question: How long do customers have to request a refund for a service they don't require?
training_pairs.answer: Customers have 21 working days from when the title fee was charged to request a refund for a service they don't require, provided they acted on LINZ guidance.
training_pairs.source_text:

resubmission fee, because the fee for registering a Gazette notice is nil.

by LINZ:

training_pairs.question: What factors does the Registrar consider when determining whether to waive or refund a fee for an unnecessary service?
training_pairs.answer: The Registrar considers two main factors: 1) the extent to which LINZ's guidance contributed to the customer's purchase of the service, and 2) whether it was reasonable for the customer to rely on the guidance provided by LINZ. However, these considerations are not limited to just these factors.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 6 of 8 
(a) the fee is the titles resubmission fee; and  
(b) the instrument being re-submitted has a nil registration or lodgement fee 
attached to it in the fee schedule. 
Example: 
A Gazette notice is re-submitted. The Registrar elects to waive the titles 
resubmission fee, because the fee for registering a Gazette notice is nil. 
2.3. The purchased service is not required 
If a customer acting on the guidance of LINZ has purchased a service they do not require 
and less than 21 working days have elapsed since the title fee was charged, then in 
determining whether to waive or refund all or any part of the fee, the Registrar will 
ordinarily consider (but is not limited to) the following matters: 
(a) the extent to which any guidance provided to customer by LINZ contributed 
to the purchase: 
(b) whether it was reasonable for the customer to rely on the guidance provided 
by LINZ:

training_pairs.question: What factors does LINZ consider when evaluating customer refund requests?
training_pairs.answer: LINZ considers three main factors: the extent of guidance provided to the customer, whether customer reliance on that guidance was reasonable, and the extent to which the customer benefited from the service.
training_pairs.source_text:
(a) the extent to which any guidance provided to customer by LINZ contributed 
to the purchase: 
(b) whether it was reasonable for the customer to rely on the guidance provided 
by LINZ: 
(c) the extent to which the customer benefited from provision of the service. 
Example:  
A customer relied on guidance they happened across in an out of date LINZ 
pamphlet when deciding to purchase a service and the service is no longer required. 
The Registrar elects not to refund the title fee, as it was unreasonable for the 
customer to rely on the guidance provided by the pamphlet. 
2.4. Charging a fee is not justified 
(1) If the Registrar considers that, in the circumstances, the amount of work in a 
particular case does not justify charging a title fee, the policy is the fee will be waived. 
(2) To avoid doubt, the circumstances in which the amount of work does not justify 
charging a title fee include (but is not limited to) where—

training_pairs.question: In what circumstances can a title fee be waived according to this text?
training_pairs.answer: A title fee can be waived when the amount of work required doesn't justify charging the fee, specifically in cases where an instrument code in an electronic document needs correction or when instruments need to be re-ordered for registration.
training_pairs.source_text:
(2) To avoid doubt, the circumstances in which the amount of work does not justify 
charging a title fee include (but is not limited to) where—  
(a) the instrument code in an electronic document has to be corrected: 
(b) instruments need to be re-ordered to enable registration. 
Example: 
A customer submits an electronic document using an incorrect instrument code 
but containing the correct image. No other amendments to the document are 
required. The Registrar elects to waive the titles resubmission fee, because the 
amount of work required to correct the code does not justify charging the title 
resubmission fee.

training_pairs.answer: The Registrar waived the titles resubmission fee because only a simple correction of an incorrect instrument code was needed, while the document's image was correct, and the amount of work required for this minor change didn't justify charging the fee.

training_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding multiple title fees charged to a customer?
training_pairs.answer: The policy states that if multiple title fees are deemed unreasonable in a particular case, only the fee of the highest amount will be charged, and the remaining fees will be waived.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 7 of 8 
2.5. It is unreasonable to charge multiple fees 
(1) If it is unreasonable for a customer to be charged multiple title fees in a particular 
case, the policy is the fee of the highest amount will be charged. The remaining fees 
will be waived.   
(2) If it is unreasonable that a customer has been charged multiple title fees in a 
particular case and less than 21 working days have elapsed since the last fee was 
charged, the policy is the fee of the highest amount will have to be paid. The 
remaining fees will be waived or refunded.    
Example: 
An instrument is lodged without some of the required documents. The instrument is 
correct in all other respects. The instrument is returned to the customer, without 
charging a new title fee, because it cannot be processed without the missing 
documents. The Registrar elects to waive the titles resubmission fee, as is

training_pairs.question: How does the refund timeframe affect the handling of multiple title fees?
training_pairs.answer: If less than 21 working days have elapsed since the last fee was charged, the highest fee must be paid while the remaining fees will be waived or refunded. After 21 working days, different rules may apply.

training_pairs.question: What is LINZ's policy regarding fee waivers when they make an error or omission?
training_pairs.answer: When LINZ makes an error or omission, their policy is to waive all or part of the title fee for any service necessary to correct that error. If the fee has already been charged, it will be refunded if less than 21 working days have passed since the charge.
training_pairs.source_text:
charging a new title fee, because it cannot be processed without the missing 
documents. The Registrar elects to waive the titles resubmission fee, as is 
unreasonable for the customer to be charged both the new title fee and the titles 
resubmission fee when they resubmit the instrument. 
2.6. Correcting an error or omission by LINZ 
(1) If a customer is to be charged a title fee for a service necessary to correct an error or 
omission by LINZ, the policy is that all or part of the fee will be waived. 
(2) If a customer has been charged a title fee for a service necessary to correct an error or 
omission by LINZ, the policy is all or part of the fee will be refunded where less than 
21 working days have elapsed since the fee was charged. 
(3) To avoid doubt, the circumstances in which a service is necessary to correct an error 
or omission by LINZ include (but are not limited to) where— 
(a) a dealing is requisitioned due to an error LINZ has made:

training_pairs.question: Why does the Registrar waive the titles resubmission fee in cases of missing documents?
training_pairs.answer: The Registrar waives the titles resubmission fee because it would be unreasonable to charge customers both a new title fee and a resubmission fee when they have to resubmit an instrument due to missing documents.

training_pairs.question: What are the circumstances where LINZ may waive fees due to their errors or omissions?
training_pairs.answer: LINZ may waive fees in two main circumstances: when a dealing is requisitioned due to an error LINZ has made, and when a dealing is requisitioned for a second time by LINZ for items they missed on the first requisition.
training_pairs.source_text:
or omission by LINZ include (but are not limited to) where— 
(a) a dealing is requisitioned due to an error LINZ has made:  
(b) a dealing is requisitioned for a second time by LINZ for items LINZ missed 
on the first requisition.  
(4) The circumstances referred to in subclause 3 do not include the Registrar exercising 
the power to alter the register under section 21 of the LTA. 
Example: 
LINZ provides incorrect advice, which results in an instrument being requisitioned. 
The Registrar elects to not charge the customer the titles resubmission fee for  
re-submitting the instrument, as the requisition was due to an error by LINZ.

training_pairs.question: How does the example provided illustrate LINZ's fee waiver policy?
training_pairs.answer: The example shows that when LINZ provides incorrect advice leading to an instrument being requisitioned, the Registrar can choose not to charge the customer the titles resubmission fee since the requisition was caused by LINZ's error.
training_pairs.source_text:
or omission by LINZ include (but are not limited to) where—

training_pairs.answer: According to subclause 3, while LINZ has various circumstances where they may waive fees for their errors or omissions, the text specifically excludes cases where the Registrar exercises their power to alter the register under section 21 of the LTA.

training_pairs.question: What happens if someone withdraws an instrument before it is registered or noted?
training_pairs.answer: According to the policy, all or any part of the title fee will be waived or refunded in accordance with Regulation 23(3) of the LTR when a customer withdraws an instrument before it is noted or registered.
training_pairs.source_text:
Waiving and Refunding Title Fees Policy 2020 
Page 8 of 8 
2.7. An instrument is withdrawn before being 
registered or noted 
If a customer withdraws an instrument before it is noted or registered, the policy is all or 
any part of the title fee will be waived or refunded, in accordance with Regulation 23(3) of 
the LTR. 
2.8. Maintaining the integrity of title to estates and 
interests in land  
(1) If the Registrar is satisfied a customer has information necessary to maintain the 
integrity of title to certain estates and interests in land, the Registrar will ordinarily 
consider the waiver of the relevant title fee to ensure the information is lodged.  
(2) To avoid doubt, maintaining the integrity of title to estates and interests in land 
means:  
(a) preventing fraud and improper dealings in land, and 
(b) maintaining public confidence in the land titles system, and 
(c) maintaining the integrity of the register and the right to claim

training_pairs.question: How does the policy help maintain the integrity of land titles?
training_pairs.answer: The policy allows the Registrar to waive title fees when customers provide information necessary to maintain title integrity. This includes preventing fraud and improper dealings, maintaining public confidence in the land titles system, and preserving the integrity of the register and right to claim.

training_pairs.question: What are the three main objectives mentioned in the beginning of the text?
training_pairs.answer: The three main objectives are: preventing fraud and improper dealings in land, maintaining public confidence in the land titles system, and maintaining the integrity of the register and the right to claim compensation under subpart 3 of part 2 of the LTA.
training_pairs.source_text:
(a) preventing fraud and improper dealings in land, and 
(b) maintaining public confidence in the land titles system, and 
(c) maintaining the integrity of the register and the right to claim 
compensation under subpart 3 of part 2 of the LTA. 
Examples:  
A customer holds information about improper dealings in land but is reluctant to 
provide the information, because doing so will incur a fee. The Registrar waives 
the fee, because they are satisfied that the information is necessary to maintain 
the integrity of title to estates and interests in land. 
An instrument has been lost by LINZ. The customer finds a copy of the instrument 
and lodges it. The Registrar declines to waive the fee for lodgement and 
registration of an instrument on the grounds of maintaining the integrity of title to 
estates and interests in land, as this is not a systemic issue. Instead, the Registrar 
elects to waive the fee for lodgement and registration of an instrument on the

training_pairs.answer: The Registrar waives the fee when they are satisfied that the information is necessary to maintain the integrity of title to estates and interests in land, encouraging the customer to provide the information about improper dealings.

training_pairs.question: Why does the Registrar decline to waive fees in the case of a lost instrument, and what alternative approach is taken?
training_pairs.answer: The Registrar declines to waive the fee based on maintaining integrity grounds because it's not a systemic issue. Instead, they elect to waive the fee for lodgement and registration specifically because LINZ lost the original instrument.

training_pairs.question: What is LINZ's policy regarding fee waivers for correcting errors?
training_pairs.answer: The Registrar waives the fee for lodgement and registration of an instrument when it is correcting an error or omission made by LINZ
